title: Hey Santa
body:
“I tried to make it Christmas and I got this hat and made all these decorations and nothing happened. I don’t get it.”

1/1

Ryan was the epitome of the type of kid Brendon’s parents specifically warned him about. Something to do with “God’s grace just doesn’t get through to everyone.” And granted, Brendon never…

Read more…

summary: Unglaublich: So sah der "Game of Thrones"-Star Jason Momoa früher aus
title: Unglaublich: So sah der "Game of Thrones"-Star Jason Momoa früher aus
body:
Den Durchbruch feierte Jason Momoa in der Erfolgsserie “Game of Thrones” – auch, wenn er als Khal Drogo bereits in der ersten Staffel ausschied. Nun ist der Schauspieler als “Aquaman” in den Kinos unterwegs. Dass er sich im Wasser wohlfühlt, hat Momoa schon vor vielen Jahren bewiesen: in seinen Rollen in der Kultserie “Baywatch”.

Wir erinnern uns: In der ersten Staffel “Game of Thrones” spielt Schauspieler Jason Momoa den Anführer des Reitervolks der Dothraki: Khal Drogo. Am Anfang furchteinflößend und wenig sympathisch, erobert der Krieger schnell das Herz seiner Ehefrau Daenerys Targaryen. Die Liebe geht so tief, dass Targaryen nicht vor dem Fluch einer Hexe zurückschreckt, um ihrem Mann das Leben zu retten. Doch das, was nach dem schwarzen Ritual von Khal übrigbleibt, hat nichts mehr mit dem stärksten Mann der Dothraki zu tun…

Na? Haben nun alle wieder die Bilder des oberkörperfreien, durchtrainierten, grimmigen Kriegers im Kopf? Gut so. Denn so kann der Kontrast zu Fotos aus jungen Schauspielertagen richtig gut wirken. Wie auf diesem hier, das Momoa nicht nur als ganz konzentrierten Rettungsschwimmer, sondern auch beim lasziven Eisverzehr zeigt.

Oder auf dem Foto hier, auf dem er mit seinen “Baywatch”-Kollegen ganz “authentisch” posiert:

Wir spulen ganz schnell wieder vor – und gucken uns lieber noch mal Khal Drogo an: in der ersten Staffel “Game of Thrones”, die auf Sky zum Stream verfügbar ist.

(Bilder: ddp / Twitter)

summary: [SPOILERS] Was this some kind of foreshadowing from Jorah Mormont in S01E02?
title: [SPOILERS] Was this some kind of foreshadowing from Jorah Mormont in S01E02?
body:
In the beginning of the episode, Ser Jorah mentioned something about a Dorthraki belief on how the world will end, he said: “In the Shadow Lands beyond Ashai, they say there are fields of ghost grass with stalks as pale as milk that glow in the night. It murders all other grass. The Dothraki believe that one day it will cover everything – that’s the way the world will end.”

Maybe it means the white walkers are the ghost grass?

Can someone interpret what he said?



Source: http://bit.ly/2Rw2nNS

title: [SPOILERS] Arya’s journey in season 6
body:
I think a lot of people are missing the point with Arya’s journey in Braavos. Both the waif and Jaquen are facets of her.

The waif is her naivety as a child. She wants the power to exact her revenge and the more she tries to convince herself she is no one, the more hostile the waif becomes. Reminding her that the reason she is there is not to become a faceless killer who has no business judging who she kills, but to gain the skills needed to kill those she has passed judgment on herself.

Jaquen represents who she thinks she wants to be- the future version she envisions herself becoming. He challenges her until she herself accepts her situation. He guides her to the truth, ultimately conveying that she must make amends with who she is in order to move into her future.

They are working in concert to bring Arya out of adolescence and into adulthood. It all culminates when Arya uses all of what she has learned from both of them to kill the Waif (her nativity) and ultimately her innocence to accept who she really is, why she really came and what she must do.

Even the play is structured toward this view: Jaquen tells her to kill the actress who’s playing cerci. If she were to become faceless like him, killing her cerci will be and feel no different than a random stranger (actress)

The waif kills the actress instead and in a spiteful and violent way, reminding her that she needs to forget becoming faceless and bring the actual cerci’s life to a violent end.

It all culminates with her killing the waif along with her innocence and nativity and realizing she has to stay a stark and kill for her own reasons. Even mounting the waifs face herself haphazardly with blood everywhere is symbolic- she will serve the god of death, but in her own way.



Source: http://bit.ly/2FbtcQJ
